comment._content:
@paulmcmahon  This photo is staged?!  Man, what kool-aid have you been drinking?  

It's ludicrous that she would go to the trouble of staging a photo; I supposed she "staged" having that thumb in the image, too?  That's how you can tell it isn't staged.  She went to great lengths to have that re-touched for her custom prints in the subsequent years.

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: paulmcmahon The photo probably *was* used for propaganda. Just about any government-approved photo can be. But the photo was not staged at all. You can read the story of how it came about here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Florence_Owens_Thompson and also see the other five images that Lange took. She literally got out of her car, walked towards the woman while taking the pictures, then left.

I discovered a series of these images in an old real to real film that was marked for discard at our university library...
It's great to see that image again. It nearly made me cry to see it thrown out. There were stories told back then that we would benefit greatly from today.

Thanks for posting this.

comment._content: This image is the perfect argument for the power of pubic domain/creative commons. When you think of how many millions of crappy photos are marked as "copyright - all rights reserved" on flickr, you have to wonder if people are deluded. Got a great photo? License it free of charge! You won't get rich, but you might get recognised. :)

comment.author: 37821541@N08
comment._content:
MOTHERS...God GRACE them for their worry... Now that my Mother is gone I remember her looking into the Larder trying to figure out HOW she was going to feed us ( 5  kids ) . Sure we were fed on grease and flour..." "WOW!! MOM , MADE deep fried DONUTS'... Not that we were rich but that was all she had. But we felt like we were rich. Cup of Mother's LOVE!! 

Now I find myself looking into the larder thinking.....How am I going to feed us???  Guess it's time to make the DONUTS!!!  HELLO,,, THE DEPRESSION is BACK!!! 

And GOD help us, I,m NOT My Mother!!

You have to admire the Worry of a Mother to feed her child!! GREAT PHOTO!!

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Christ on Crutches: The addition of the 'Migrant Mother' by Lange and the other selected images from the black-and-white negatives of the Farm Security Administration/Office of War Information Collection is our first foray into sharing that part of the FSA/OWI Collection on Flickr. The entire black-and-white portion of the FSA/OWI Collection, numbering over 171,000 negatives, is available in the Prints & Photographs Online Catalog, including this one of Allie Mae Burroughs and others of the rest of the Burroughs family. (More information about, as well as a link to search within the black-and-white negatives of the FSA/OWI Collection can be found here). We are exploring ways to share more of the FSA/OWI Collection, as well as other collections from our holdings, in Flickr and are glad to hear there is an interest for more of these historic images!

comment.author: 38918524@N04
comment._content: This photo by Dorothea Lange was part of the Family of Man exhibit by Edward Steichen in the 1950's for MoMA. The exhibit was published in catalog from in various editions. Perhaps this has bearing on copyright? en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Family_of_Man My family owned one of the exhibit catalogs and that is where I recall this seeing and growing up with this picture. However, it may be that Steichen culled from the Library of Congress for the original exhibit?

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Dorothea Lange took the photograph on assignment for the Farm Security Administration, i.e. it was "work for hire" for the U.S. Government. Since the U.S. Government cannot hold copyright the picture is in the public domain and can be re-published by anyone (including the MoMA).

comment.author: 51035799100@N01
comment._content: Norma, the baby in the pictures, said of her mother that she “… was a woman who loved to enjoy life, who loved her children. She loved music and she loved to dance. When I look at that photo of mother [the Migrant Mother], it saddens me. That’s not how I like to remember her.” Troy recalled about his childhood years, “They were tough, tough times, but they were the best times we ever had.” Norma agreed: “We also had our fun.” — The Other Migrant Mother by Michael Stones

comment.author: 67071106@N00
comment._content: nothing beats the Graflex 4x5" images, looks like it was a kodak 400iso negative, but a mirror image of the negative? did the photographer load her negative wrong or is the negative mirror image more convenient like that, for people that read from left to right?

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: avalonux What makes you think it's 400 ISO? When Kodak launched Tri-X as a "high speed film" in 1954, its maximum speed was 200. This photo was taken in 1936, when I don't think "fast" film was available. The text on negatives is always back to front in my experience.

comment.author: 30670636@N06
comment._content: interesting how Lange missed critical focus on the face of the woman. look at the image at full size and you will find that the sharpest area of the image is in the boy's hair.

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: andrew.allen97 I think that's an illusion because the hair is more contrasty. Mrs. Thompson's hand is sharp, as is her shirt collar, and the elbow of the boy on the right. When you consider Lange was hand-holding a large format camera fifteen feet away in a muddy field, I think she did bloody well to get anything in focus!

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content:
Actually, there is no boy in the picture :)

Having spent an hour plus cleaning this picture, I can say with some authority that the area most in focus is her cleavage... (well, actually the checkered shirt she's wearing). That's something you'll notice if you print the picture at about 25x20" (at 300ppi), or about five times as big as the original.

comment.author: 30670636@N06
comment._content:
well the child's hair (on the right) is on the same plane as the shirt, correct? and wouldn't that make the face of the woman in front of the focal plane? and yes, arturo, i didn't take that into account. that is quite impressive.

regardless, my point was that the woman's face is not quite in focus. I'm wondering if it was deliberate or not.

great photo nonetheless

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content:
Possibly, it's just easier to locate the focal plane based on patterns like the checkers on the shirt or the knitting of the cardigan than hair... 

As Arturo said, with the technical limitations of the day and the context of the shoot (Florence Owen was less a willing participant than a passive subject, and Lange likely didn't want to overstay her welcome) it's unlikely that the focus was deliberately off.

comment.author: 30670636@N06
comment._content: got it. thanks

comment._content: Que triste la foto!

comment.author: 52149095@N00

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/52149095@N00/] The one girl that didn't want her picture taken was the eldest daughter that can be seen in the first photo of the series – she's not in this picture. The younger ones took it more as an opportunity to goof off in front of the camera. This particular view, with the girls turning their backs to the camera, was arranged by Dorothea Lange.

comment.author: 52149095@N00
comment._content: Ah!...Thanks Triasanderrors, very interesting to hear the story behind it.......it's an amazing photo...with great emotion...

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: If this is a scan of the negative, then it's the negative of a copy of the original, with the thumb burned out. What happened to the original negative? Did Lange destroy it?

comment.author: 44507842@N04
comment._content: amazing !!!!!!

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: …trialsanderrors wrote "This particular view, with the girls turning their backs to the camera, was arranged by Dorothea Lange." What is your source for that statement? I don't believe Lange asked them to pose, if that's what you are implying. The removal of the thumb in later versions of the print is one thing, but Lange was a documentary photographer. She said of her approach to her work "What I photograph, I do not molest or tamper with or arrange. I try to make a picture as part of its surroundings, as having roots". The children may have "posed" themselves as Lange took the five photos, getting nearer to Mrs Thompson each time. History doesn't record any actual dialogue between Lange or her subjects. She took the photos, and then drove away.

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/artysmokes/] If this is a scan of the negative, then it's the negative of a copy of the original, with the thumb burned out. What happened to the original negative? The thumb was burned out of the negative some time after the original prints were made, so this is a scan of the negative as it appears now. A print of the original version was discovered only recently and is part of the LoC collection. History doesn't record any actual dialogue between Lange or her subjects. Actually, Florence Owen's children claim that Lange promised her mom that the pictures would not be published (a pretty implausible claim, given Lange's job description). What is your source for that statement? I don't believe Lange asked them to pose, if that's what you are implying. I'll have to get back to you on the source (there are dozens discussing the picture and the belated response of the family), but her statement can hardly be taken at face value. Lange took some 4000 pictures for the RA/FSA alone, and quite a few show clear signs of interaction with her subjects. Lange had a reputation of being able to make herself nearly invisible if she wanted to, but clearly the Owens family noticed and responded to her. By the time Lange took the "Migrant Mother" picture, she was close enough so that the girls could simply stay out of the picture if they didn't want to appear in it (as some of them they did on the earlier shots). For them to get back into the picture and then to turn their heads is not a plausible scenario if the agreed-upon sequence is indeed the correct one.

comment.author: 66853325@N00
comment._content: …trialsanderrors wrote "The thumb was burned out of the negative some time after the original prints were made." Just a technique question, but how does one do that? I know how dodging and burning is done during the enlarging/printing process, but how does someone "burn" the negative?

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: I profess ignorance on the technical part of the question. The LoC description states "The negative was retouched in the 1930s to erase the thumb holding a tent pole in lower right hand corner." — "Burning" might not be the correct term...

comment._content: My favorite picture of all time.  Read the information on this photo and you can see why.  This image change lives, documented history, achieved a new approach in photojournalism, and represented my family heritage.  Yes, I came from a family of migrate works.  My father, uncles, aunts and grandparents all picked produce from Oklahoma to California.  Dorothea Lange's was a amazing woman during a amazing time in American History.
